Gentlemen Of the Senate


And Of The House Of Representatives..


In closing my exercise of he supreme executive
powers Of the Stale do not perceive the neccSsty
Of recommending to your consideration any mea
sures which have not been heretofore submitted TO
you by myself or by my predecessors, or which the
General Assembly has not already had under its
notice. This consider strong proof Of the
happy condition of our fellow citizens. We are in
more danger OF suffering by innovations, than from
deficiency OF legislation. Our State constitution
and the constitution Of the United States arc sui
Client to insure us all our rights and privileges a
people, and, a, long as they BE- preserved, to

Blessed as we are and have been with peace at
home and abroad, with plenty in our land, and with
reasonable degree Of health at presen, and through
the last summer and autumn, propose to you,
gentlemen, that you should Sc: apar, day, during
your session, and recommend the same to be kept
by the people of the State, as day Of prayer and
Thanksgiving TO Almighty God for his goodness
his raerces and all other blessings of his providence
The sincere alteration and grateful offering OF
thanks OF a whole people may be an acceptable ser
vice to Him, from whom cometh every good and
perfect gift and who hath bountfuy bestowed on US
the comforts OF this lfe and the means of eyerlast
ng salvation.


Before bid you adieu, must beg you, gentle
men, to accept my sincere thanks for the courtesy
which have received from the Legislature during
my adminisration-an administration certainly not
faul,less. but without any faults arising from nen-
!ion, or from any evil motives


SAMUEL PAINTER.


Dorer, January a, 1897.

Messrs. r. PORTER & G. W. MrTz Of this BOROUGH
have issued Proposals for publishing the Fifth Volume Of
The Laws of Delaware II is seldom that even a second
hand copy Of the 5h vol Of the Of this State can be
had, and then only at very high price. Persons, there
fore, who wish 10 procure copy reasonable terms,
would do well to avail themselves Of this opportunity with
out delay, the work will he put press in ABOUT 5
weeks, and few if any, copies will be printed than
are subscribed for The volume will be ready for delivery
about the first Of June next and the price TO subscribers
will be 81, bound.

NOTICE.

The ship Josephine. Captain Coles. fiom Liver.
pool, anchored below the Narrows yesterday alter
noon. BY this arrival The Editors OF the CONNER
cial Hduertispr have reeeived regular file Of Lon.
don papers TO the evening Of tile 18th inclusive.


Parliament re-assembsd on the 18th.


A letter from Liverpool, says-TEe complaints
Of dullness in trade rather increase We have very
fiat accounts from Manchester.


a Glasgow paper says G the poor laboring peo
ple are now obliged 10 wash their clothes without
soap, go to bed without candle, and to live on
oatmeal, potatoes, and fish, and such other articles
as are the produce Of the districts in which they
reside


The woolen trade OF Saddle worth, which depends
much upon exports, principally to The States con.
tinues extremely depressed. In the township Of
DELPHI alone, there are At present no fewer than
$500 persons Oh the list of paupers.


The artisans in Lancashire and Yorkshire are in
deplorabie state. Many families once in the en-
Ioyment OF many comforts, now unable by the
most arduous labor, to procure the common neces-
saries of life.


A branch Of the Bank # England is to be opened
in Liverpool. Samuel Turner, Esq. ia appointed
chief manager.


A paper of the last date says--"It is stated on
good authority that the Turks have at last yielded
to the remonstrances of England and France on The
subject oi the Greeks and that arrangement los
the independence of Greece will be made, on terms
less favorable to the Porte than has been formerly
proposed"


The Calcutta Government Gazette contains an
account OF the British agent at he Burmese court
taking possession Ct the newly acquired territory in
Buim nah, which was performed about the end of
March, by the agent, MIR. Crawfnrd, 10 company
with several officers, and Mr. Judson, the American
missionary.


The Portuguese Minister Of War writes from
Faro. that the rebellion OF Tavira is wholly pus
down, and that it was almost entirely confined to
the military; not 20 Agai yians being found imph-
Gated,


BY the ship Cowper, Capt. Uran, arrived a, New
York on Saturday last, from London, London papers
to the evening Of the 2lst Of November, inclusive.
have been received.


The Russian beiligerent operations against Persia
are suspended by the accounts from Odessa
Nothing will be done Till next spring. The Rus
slams have great deserts and mountains TO cross be-
fore they reach the Persians. Abbar Mira
was defeated on The l3ih September.


The Turkish feet has returned TO The Dardanel.
les without attack king Samos. The Mediterranean
swarms with Greek pirates.

The ship Josephine. Captain Coles. fiom Liver.
pool, anchored below the Narrows yesterday alter
noon. BY this arrival The Editors OF the CONNER
cial Hduertispr have reeeived regular file Of Lon.

Parliament re-assembsd on the 18th.


A letter from Liverpool, says-TEe complaints
Of dullness in trade rather increase We have very
fiat accounts from Manchester.


a Glasgow paper says G the poor laboring peo
ple are now obliged 10 wash their clothes without
soap, go to bed without candle, and to live on
oatmeal, potatoes, and fish, and such other articles
as are the produce Of the districts in which they
reside


The woolen trade OF Saddle worth, which depends
much upon exports, principally to The States con.
tinues extremely depressed. In the township Of
DELPHI alone, there are At present no fewer than
$500 persons Oh the list of paupers.


The artisans in Lancashire and Yorkshire are in
deplorabie state. Many families once in the en-
Ioyment OF many comforts, now unable by the
most arduous labor, to procure the common neces-
saries of life.


A branch Of the Bank # England is to be opened
in Liverpool. Samuel Turner, Esq. ia appointed
chief manager.


A paper of the last date says--"It is stated on
good authority that the Turks have at last yielded
to the remonstrances of England and France on The
subject oi the Greeks and that arrangement los
the independence of Greece will be made, on terms
less favorable to the Porte than has been formerly
proposed"


The Calcutta Government Gazette contains an
account OF the British agent at he Burmese court
taking possession Ct the newly acquired territory in
Buim nah, which was performed about the end of
March, by the agent, MIR. Crawfnrd, 10 company
with several officers, and Mr. Judson, the American
missionary.


The Portuguese Minister Of War writes from
Faro. that the rebellion OF Tavira is wholly pus
down, and that it was almost entirely confined to
the military; not 20 Agai yians being found imph-
Gated,


BY the ship Cowper, Capt. Uran, arrived a, New
York on Saturday last, from London, London papers
to the evening Of the 2lst Of November, inclusive.
have been received.


The Russian beiligerent operations against Persia
are suspended by the accounts from Odessa
Nothing will be done Till next spring. The Rus
slams have great deserts and mountains TO cross be-
fore they reach the Persians. Abbar Mira
was defeated on The l3ih September.


The Turkish feet has returned TO The Dardanel.
les without attack king Samos. The Mediterranean
swarms with Greek pirates.

Washington, January 4.-It is reported (and
beleved) tina. JOEL X. PoINsETT has been
nominated by the PRESIDENT Of the United States
to the Senate, to be Minister to Panama, alias Tacu
baya, vice RICHARD c. ANDERSON deceased.
1t is also reported (and belieyed) that WILLIAM
JONES has been nominated to be Collector Of the
Revenue for the port of Philadelphia, vice JOHN
STEELE, resigned.


We learn, unofficially, that the following gentle

United States, with the advice and consent of the
